org.bbi.linuxjoy

Class LinuxJoystick

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.bbi.linuxjoy.LinuxJoystick
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    NoJoy, SocketJoystick

    public class LinuxJoystick
extends java.lang.Object
    LinuxJoystick is a class that uses the Linux joystick API and presents a nice interface to be used in Java applications. The class uses Java's new I/O system to support asynchronous operation.

    • Field Detail

      • fc

        protected java.nio.channels.spi.AbstractInterruptibleChannel fc
        The data source I/O channel. Used by the channelOpen() and channelRead() functions to open and read the data source. Subclasses overriding the specified functions will have to cast this object to the appropriate channel implementation. The default implementation uses FileChannel

      • path

        protected java.lang.String path
        Path to the data source. This path refers to the joystick device file for the default implementation.

      • buf

        protected java.nio.ByteBuffer buf
        Internal read buffer. This buffer is filled by the channelRead() function

      • deviceOpen

        protected boolean deviceOpen
        A flag that signifies whether the device is still open and ready for reading. Any part of the program that determines that the device is stale should set this flag to false.

    • Constructor Detail

      • LinuxJoystick

        public LinuxJoystick(java.lang.String path,
             int buttons,
             int axes)
        Create a new Joystick object
        Parameters:
        path - Path to the system device file, typically in /dev/input
        buttons - Number of buttons that the controller has
        axes - Number of axes that the controller has

    • Method Detail

      • startPollingThread

        public void startPollingThread(int sleepMs)
        Start a polling thread that will periodically read the controller device file and update the current states
        Parameters:
        sleepMs - Polling interval in milliseconds

      • stopPollingThread

        public void stopPollingThread()
        Stop the polling thread. This does not interrupt the thread if it is currently blocking on read. Use close() to interrupt the thread and close the device.

      • open

        public final void open()
        Open the joystick device given by the path. Override channelOpen() if data source is not coming from a file.

      • isDeviceOpen

        public boolean isDeviceOpen()
        Check if this joystick object currenty has a joystick device open
        Returns:
        True if a channel is currently open, false otherwise

      • close

        public void close()
        Close the device file. Running this function while the polling thread is running will stop the thread

      • channelRead

        protected int channelRead()
                   throws java.io.IOException
        The channel read routine. This defaults to reading from a file. This function can be overridden if other channel types are desired.
        Returns:
        Number of bytes read
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - I/O exception is thrown from this function

      • channelOpen

        protected boolean channelOpen()
        The channel open routine. By default, the channel is implemented as a FileChannel. Override this function if other data input type is needed.
        Returns:
        True if open is successful, false otherwise

      • channelClose

        protected void channelClose()
        The channel close routine. Override this function if other input type is needed and it is not a channel

      • poll

        public void poll()
        Poll the device. This is a blocking operation. Use the polling thread for asynchronous operation.

      • setCallback

        public void setCallback(LinuxJoystickEventCallback cb)
        Specify a callback object to execute after an event occurs. Note that the joystick states are updated before the callback is performed, so getButtonState and getAxisState will return the latest value. Pass a "null" object to unregister the callback.
        Parameters:
        cb - Reference to callback object.

      • setCloseCallback

        public void setCloseCallback(LinuxJoystickEventCallback cb)
        Specify a callback object to execute when the joystick device is closed
        Parameters:
        cb - Reference to callback object

      • getButtonState

        public boolean getButtonState(int index)
        Get the state of the button given by the index
        Parameters:
        index - The button index value
        Returns:
        True if the button is being pressed, false otherwise

      • getAxisState

        public int getAxisState(int index)
        Get the state of the axis given by the index
        Parameters:
        index - The axis index value
        Returns:
        A number between -2^16 to 2^16-1 that represents the axis value

      • getNumButtons

        public int getNumButtons()
        Give the total number of buttons that this joystick object was defined with
        Returns:
        Number of buttons

      • getNumAxes

        public int getNumAxes()
        Give the total number of axes that this joystick object was defined with
        Returns:
        Number of axes

      • setButtonsAxes

        public void setButtonsAxes(int buttons,
                  int axes)
        Set new number of buttons and axes. Should not need to do this often, only if the program needs to determine the number of buttons and axes immediately after instantiation
        Parameters:
        buttons - Number of buttons that the controller has
        axes - Number of axes that the controller has

      • isChanged

        public boolean isChanged()
        Check if there has been a change in state since the last poll
        Returns:
        True if the controller state has changed, false otherwise

      • toString

        public java.lang.String toString()
        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
